description: Borrowed from Middle French charte (“card, map”), from Late Latin charta (“paper, card, map”), Latin charta (“papyrus, writing”), from Ancient Greek χάρτης (khártēs, “papyrus, thin sheet”). See charter, card, carte.

entries.meaning: A map illustrating the geography of a specific phenomenon.

definitionGroups.group: A systematic non-narrative presentation of data.

entries.meaning: A tabular presentation of data; a table.
A record of a patient's diagnosis, care instructions, and recent history.
examples: I snuck a look at his chart. It doesn't look good.

entries.meaning: A ranked listing of competitors, as of recorded music.
examples: They're at the top of the charts again this week.

entries.meaning: (differential geometry, topology) Synonym of coordinate chart.

verbs.description: chart (third-person singular simple present charts, present participle charting, simple past and past participle charted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To draw a chart or map of.
(transitive) To draw or figure out (a route or plan).
examples: Let's chart how we're going to get from here to there.
We are on a course for disaster without having charted it.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a record or artist) To appear on a hit-recording chart.
examples: The song has charted for 15 weeks!
